messages.subject: internet educational newsletters for the kids!
messages.msgSnippet: Melanie, Heather & others: Here s something I thought you d be interested in... Fwd: Alphabetically Yours: Volume 2 Issue Dd  (see below) I also get KinderArt
messages.messageBody:
Melanie, Heather & others:

Here's something I thought you'd be interested in...
Fwd: Alphabetically Yours: Volume 2 Issue Dd (see below)

I also get KinderArt each month with projects and artsy ideas for the kids
to do...
And I subscribe to the "Trucker Buddy" program which follows a Semi-Truck
driver around the USA and teaches us about his loads and geography...

Email me privately if anyone would like more info... (don't want to offend
anyone with bunches of tid bits for your web site & other learning
experiences...)

Diana A.
"the world is our classroom"


----Original Message Follows----
From: anne@...
To: diasberry@...
Subject: Alphabetically Yours: Volume 2 Issue Dd
Date: Sun, 5 Sep 1999 15:59:32 -0400

Welcome to the fourth edition of Alphabetically Yours, Volume 2 Issue Dd. I
am looking forward to introducing you to a multitude of activities,
suggestions, and tips for Having Fun with the Alphabet. Please feel free to
write with any questions and comments. I will answer back A.S.A.P.
Anne@...

Mrs. Alphabet announces a yearly membership to Mrs. Alphabet's Family. You
can be part of this learning community and teach your students and/or
children using all of Mrs. Alphabet's 32 years of experience and expertise.

Alphabetically Yours Newsletters will be free with the purchase of the
yearly membership only. The newsletters will be accessed on the secure site
only beginning with Volume 2 Issue Ff. View samples of Mrs. Alphabet's
curriculum for alphabet recognition and phonics. View samples of Mrs.
Alphabet's Rainbow Reading Code. Now for the first time, you can be part of
this learning community and teach your students and/or children using all of
Mrs. Alphabet's 32 years of experience and expertise.

Mrs. Alphabet's Family: http://mrsalphabet.com/sample1.html.
Mrs. Alphabet's Family: http://mrsalphabet.com/sample2.html.

Rainbow Reading Code does not have the audio files installed yet and until
they are complete you will be temporarily receiving 2 memberships for the
price of 1.

Rainbow Reading Code: http://mrsalphabet.com/sample3.html
Rainbow Reading Code: Http://mrsalphabet.com/sample4.html

Dd Activities:

Alphabet Animal Sound Game
By Mrs. Alphabet: Letter Dd

Dance like a dinosaur at the park
Dancing at midnight in the dark!
Hear the d sound in my name
Play the d sound animal game!

Dinosaur Delights:
Memory Game: http://www.geocities.com/Heartland/6459/actpag50.html
Dress Up Game:
http://disney.go.com/DisneyBooks/Author/Dinorella/Dinoactivity.html
Jigsaw Puzzles: http://www.kidsdomain.com/down/pc/winzledinop1.html
Dinosaur Party: http://www.boardmanweb.com/party/dino.htm
Dinosaur Museum http://www.a1.com/children/dino.htm
Dinosaur Jokes:
http://www.EnchantedLearning.com/subjects/dinosaurs/Dinojokes.html
Scramble Dinosaurs:
http://www.EnchantedLearning.com/Slidedinosaurs/Slidedino2.html

Denver By Mrs. Alphabet

Use this poem to identify spot D names and to elicit new D names. Write out
on sentence strips, place in a pocket chart, and then brainstorm other
places to live that begin with B from your class.

David, Dot, and Dino live in Denver with me
Dina, Dusty, and Dominic want to visit and see.
What other D kids do you think live there,
In delightful Denver far away from here?

Interview 6 people and ask them this question: Can you dive? Record the
results.

Now isn't this ducky: http://www.alaska.net/~cccandc/ducks.htm

Take an imaginary trip on a donkey. Write or have children dictate a story
and illustrate. Display children's work in a book form.

Visit Delaware; locate on your map or globe, then go to:
http://www.state.de.us/

Use dots as counters or for simple math problems: estimating, counting,
graphing, adding, sorting, patterns, subtracting, or bingo markers.

Ask the children to bring in dominoes to compare, contrast, and collect.

Dice Math can incorporate counting, graphing, sorting, measuring,
predicting, and comparing.

Use different size stuffed dogs for a math lesson demonstrating: color,
shape, size, sorting, and counting.

Graph how many children were born in Delaware.

Graph how many children have dogs.

Graph how many children take dance lessons .

Develop a list of Disney characters and then go here:
http://disney.go.com/home/homepage/index.html? and please be sure to visit
my friend Cathy Disney's site at: http://members.tripod.com/~luvdisney/

Discuss a dictionary and then go here to display an online dictionary:
http://www.enchantedlearning.com/cgi-bin/F2.cgi/

Use a telephone book to find D names.

If I were a doctor I would _________________, but I wouldn't
__________________.

If I were a dentist I would _____________________, but I wouldn't
__________________.

If I were dirty I would _____________________, but I wouldn't
__________________. Then make this delicious treat:
http://www.ichef.com/ichef-recipes/Cakes/3515.html

Create a predictable chart. "I like ____________ donuts." Another
predictable chart is "My favorite day is ______________________."
Play and teach the children the lyrics to this song:
http://www.fiftiesweb.com/lyrics/dayo.htm

Create class d charts of words, and place child's name at the end of his/her
sentence.

Find objects that are dark in color.

Don't miss out on this darling game:
http://www.billybear4kids.com/games/stickers/dolhouse/stickers.htm

Ask the children to analyze what they think is used to make a Dove bar by
tasting and observing the contents. Then read off and list the ingredients.
Check off the items that the children guessed. Remember check for milk
allergies.

List names that begin with D and talk about what you see or hear.

Check names in the class for D sounds. Make a graph of children that have
the D sound in their name.

Read a poem and have children color code all the d words.

Copy and blow up this rhebus version of Diddle Diddle Dumpling My Son John:
http://www.enchantedlearning.com/rhymes/Diddle.shtml

Dot to Dot Fun: http://www.kidsdomain.com/down/pc/dottodotanc.html

Mini- Lesson: Generating words from the word : door do, odor, or, rod,

Mini Lesson: Try introducing this d word: desk. Ask the children what they
notice about the word.

Mini Lesson: Cover and reveal 1 letter at a time. Children try to guess
the word: dear dog dash dinner dust

Mini Lesson: Introduce a new word for vocabulary: double Discuss double.
and then make this delightful treat:
http://www.ichef.com/ichef-recipes/Candies/3328.html

Mini Lesson: Observation and Language Arts:
http://www.mindspring.com/~zoonet/galleries/deer.htm

Whose family has the most D names?

Use these words to rhyme: dab date dear dim dog dug

Tongue Twister: Dirty Dave digs deep down.

Give 3 reasons you think children like desert.

Order your students in a line from D to C.

D Artist: Salvatore Dali: http://www.artchive.com/ftp_site.htm

D Books: The Day Jimmy's Boa Ate The Wash; Dear Zoo; Doctor De Soto

D Author: Tomie DePalo: http://www.opendoor.com/bingley/mywebpage.html

D Composer: Claude Debussy: http://www.prs.net/debussy.html
